author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Judge Rejects State Law Aimed at Controlling Progressive Cities
description: The law, which sought to block local rules like those requiring water breaks, was part of a push by Republican state leaders to exert control over Democratic-led cities.
content: A Texas district court judge ruled on Wednesday that a new state law aimed at preventing cities from making local rules on a broad range of subjects — including requiring rest breaks for construction workers — was unconstitutional, siding with the leaders of Houston, San Antonio and other Texas cities who had challenged the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: When Your ‘Doppelganger’ Becomes a Conspiracy Theorist
description: If you’re Naomi Klein, you write a book about it.
content: In June, the Canadian journalist and activist Naomi Klein was sitting in the dark gray booth of a recording studio in Lower Manhattan. Dressed simply for the New York City heat — white linen top, light cropped pants, white sneakers — she was reading from a script, and there was a line that was giving her a bit of trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sola Mahfouz
title: ‘Freedom’ Is a Word I No Longer Trust
description: Afghanistan has always been at the mercy of would-be liberators.
content: When the United States freed Afghanistan from the first Taliban government in 2001, everything in my homeland seemed to change overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: ‘Bee Emergency’: How Beekeepers Got 5 Million Bees Off a Road in Ontario
description: A dozen beekeepers converged to help rescue a swarm of angry bees that escaped when their boxes fell off a truck in Burlington, Ontario, on Wednesday.
content: The call of duty for Terri Faloney, a beekeeper in Hamilton, Ontario, came on Wednesday at around 8 a.m. Her mother had just seen a report on television that five million angry bees had escaped from wooden boxes that had toppled off a trailer and were swarming a two-lane road in nearby Burlington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Two lines of attack.
content: Russian forces are advancing in northeastern Ukraine, toward the battered city of Kupiansk, while Ukraine presses its offensive in the south.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: How a Fight Club Starts in ‘Bottoms’
description: The director Emma Seligman narrates a sequence from her film featuring Rachel Sennott and Ayo Edebiri.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
description: This month’s picks include a look back at a presidential primary, a remembrance of the victims of a hate crime and an intriguing visit to a Northwest Atlantic island.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Reviving America’s Fading Cities Isn’t Impossible
description: But it requires a clearer aim — and a lot more money.
content: Here is a list of the biggest U.S. cities by population in 1900: New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, St. Louis, Boston, Baltimore, Cleveland, Buffalo, San Francisco and Cincinnati. Some of those cities have continued to thrive, but others have faded. This year Baltimore is the 30th biggest city, Cleveland 54th, St. Louis 75th and Buffalo 79th.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: Cousins (and Co-Authors) Write a Love Letter to New York
description: Jillian and Mariko Tamaki have created award-winning graphic novels together. Their new book, “Roaming,” is an ode to the city that captivated them and the thrills of young adulthood.
content: In the new graphic novel “Roaming,” Dani and Zoe, best friends from a suburb of Toronto, meet up in Manhattan over spring break. It’s 2009, and the teenagers have dreamed of visiting the city together, seeing the sights and reconnecting after several months apart. Before long, they’re savoring their first slice of New York pizza (“huge, like a place mat!”) and getting hassled for cash by a creepy Times Square busker dressed as Elmo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: For $200, a Person Can Fuel the Decline of Our Major Parties
description: Small donors may not be such a good thing.
content: One of the most important developments driving political polarization over the past two decades is the growth in small-dollar contributions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Former Cardinal McCarrick Found Unfit for Trial Over Sexual Abuse
description: The 93-year-old former prelate is the most senior cleric to face charges in the Catholic Church’s abuse crisis.
content: Theodore McCarrick, the highest-ranking Catholic cleric in the United States to face charges in the church’s ongoing sexual abuse crisis, is not competent to stand trial, a judge in Massachusetts ruled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ray Hildebrand, the ‘Paul’ of Hitmakers Paul and Paula, Dies at 82
description: He wrote a romantic song for his friend’s girlfriend, Paula, and recorded it as a duet with Jill Jackson. It became a No. 1 hit.
content: Ray Hildebrand, whose recording with a friend, Jill Jackson, of a love song he wrote in college, “Hey Paula,” became a No. 1 hit in 1963 and brought them instant fame as Paul and Paula, died on Aug. 18 at his home in Overland Park, Kan. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin, Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
title: Mark Thompson Helped Steady 2 News Outlets. Can He Do the Same at CNN?
description: Mr. Thompson, who oversaw a period of growth at The New York Times and the BBC, will lead the network during a pivotal period.
content: Mark Thompson, a former top executive at The New York Times Company and the BBC, was touring wine country in the south of France with his wife in mid-June when an unexpected call came in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Hiroko Masuike
title: Life at a Grand Slam: What You Don’t See on TV at the U.S. Open
description: The commute, the fight for court time and the sponsorship commitments make the life of a tennis player demanding during this tournament.
content: When Mackenzie McDonald dueled Félix Auger-Aliassime for three and a half hours in the opening round of the U.S. Open, fans were only seeing a glimpse of the time McDonald put in toward his surprise win on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Luke Broadwater
title: McCarthy Tries to Leverage Biden Impeachment to Avoid a Shutdown
description: But some conservatives are dismissive, saying the House could continue investigating the president and his family even if funding for the government lapses at the end of September.
content: Facing the prospect of a politically damaging government shutdown within weeks, House Speaker Kevin McCarthy is offering a new argument to conservatives reluctant to vote to keep funding flowing: A shutdown would make it more difficult for Republicans to pursue an impeachment inquiry against President Biden, or to push forward with investigations of him and his family that could yield evidence for one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: A Category 4 Hurricane
description: Idalia is barreling toward Florida.
content: Hurricane Idalia intensified overnight and is now a Category 4 storm heading toward Florida’s Gulf Coast. It has wind speeds of 130 miles an hour and is expected to make landfall around 8 a.m Eastern, bringing catastrophic waves and potentially submerging the coast in up to 16 feet of flooding. You can track the storm’s path here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Falsehoods Follow Close Behind This Summer’s Natural Disasters
description: Misattributed videos, recycled lies and warped fears are fueling unfounded claims about the recent record-breaking heat, floods and wildfires.
content: As natural disasters and extreme environmental conditions became more commonplace around the world this summer, scientists pointed repeatedly to a shared driver: climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Nigeria Arrests Dozens Over Same-Sex Wedding
description: A 2014 law makes such unions illegal in the country. Anyone found guilty of taking part can also face up to 10 years in prison.
content: The police in Nigeria have arrested over 60 people who were in attendance at what the authorities claimed was a same-sex wedding, reinforcing a crackdown on L.G.B.T.Q. people in Africa’s most populous nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Girlfriend Wants a Real Diamond Ring. Can It Be Lab-Grown Instead?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the perils of inaugurating an engagement with deception.
content: My girlfriend and I have been dating for over two years, and I’m seriously considering proposing to her. In researching different types of engagement rings, I’ve begun to see, no pun intended, clear-cut differences between lab-grown and natural diamonds. While natural diamonds fall under a classic aesthetic, lab-grown diamonds are better for the environment and a better value (I could afford a larger carat) and don’t perpetuate the cruel abuses that take place during their mining.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: 16 Books to Read in September
description: New novels from Zadie Smith, Stephen King and Lauren Groff; Walter Isaacson’s hotly anticipated Elon Musk biography; a history of the AR-15 assault rifle; and much more.
content: What are the dangers — and opportunities — of artificial intelligence? This new novel confronts these questions through the story of a renowned but financially struggling poet in her 70s, who accepts a tech company’s offer to co-write a poem with an A.I. program in exchange for a lucrative paycheck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack and Rob Stothard
title: He Was Shot 14 Times at the Dinner Table. His Children Want to Know if Britain Ordered the Hit.
description: Proposed legislation may keep them from ever finding out.
content: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — John and Michael Finucane were children in 1989 when paramilitary gunmen smashed in the front door with a sledgehammer in the middle of Sunday dinner and opened fire. Their father, the human rights lawyer Pat Finucane, was still clutching his fork when he succumbed to his 14 bullet wounds. Michael, his eldest child, remembers cowering under the kitchen table with his younger siblings while “Only Fools and Horses,” a British sitcom, droned through his father’s killing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Has Been Easing Fast, but Wild Cards Lie Ahead
description: Will inflation continue to slow at a solid pace? Economists are warily watching a few key areas, like housing and cars.
content: President Biden has openly celebrated recent inflation reports, and Federal Reserve officials have also breathed a sigh of relief as rapid price gains show signs of losing steam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Idalia Sweeps Through Georgia After Pelting Florida’s Coast
description: Also, drones hit deep inside Russia. Here's the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Hurricane Idalia made landfall this morning in Florida’s Big Bend, hitting the area with heavy rain and devastating winds before marching northeast into Georgia. The storm severed power to hundreds of thousands of homes and left behind life-threatening floods across wide swaths of the region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Struggling to Understand TV Dialogue? Join the Club.
description: Readers discuss a tech column offering solutions. Also: Airbrushing older models; Haley’s raised hand; sea life in captivity.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Republican Women, Fearing Backlash on Abortion, Pivot to Birth Control
description: A group of politically vulnerable G.O.P. women has backed legislation that purports to expand birth control access but would have little effect. Critics say the bill is meant to distract from their anti-abortion stances.
content: She had barely opened her town hall to questions when Representative Mariannette Miller-Meeks, a Republican from a competitive district in Iowa, was pressed to defend her opposition to abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: In a Storied River, Fish Are Dying in Droves as Climate Change Scorches Canada
description: The effects of a summer of environmental catastrophes were felt everywhere in Canada, from its vast boreal forests to a river on Vancouver Island once fished by Hollywood royalty.
content: The salmon were once so plentiful in the river that old-timers talk about having been able to cross on the backs of fish so thick they were like steppingstones. Such was the renown of the Cowichan River, flowing east on Canada’s Vancouver Island, that its fly-fishing conditions were posted in fishing clubs in London. John Wayne and Bing Crosby were regulars in Cowichan Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: In Annie Baker’s Plays, Pay Attention to the Pauses
description: Her work, including the new “Infinite Life,” involves silences full of meaning. But what exactly they convey can change depending on the director.
content: “The Flick,” a play by Annie Baker, had its premiere at Playwrights Horizons in 2013. Its three hour and 15 minute runtime included long stretches in which the characters — three underpaid workers in a tired, single-screen movie theater — moved from row to row, sweeping the floor. The drama found a kind of poetry in everyday speech: the hesitations, filler words, abandoned sentences and otherwise awkward attempts to connect. A lot of the time, Baker’s characters didn’t speak at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Dire Consequences of Depleting California’s Groundwater
description: A New York Times investigation reveals that overuse is draining and damaging aquifers nationwide.
content: In an average year in California, roughly 40 percent of the state’s water supply comes from groundwater — the water that fills a well, naturally stored beneath our feet in aquifers. In a dry year, the share of the state’s water needs that are met from this hidden resource can exceed 60 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada Cautions L.G.B.T.Q. Citizens Visiting U.S. Over State Laws
description: Advice that travelers to the U.S. “check relevant state and local laws” came in response to rules this year restricting transgender care, drag shows and sports participation.
content: The Canadian government is warning L.G.B.T.Q. travelers to the United States that they may be affected by a series of recently enacted state laws that restrict transgender and other gay people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Makes Lower Drug Prices a Centerpiece of His 2024 Campaign
description: President Biden’s Inflation Reduction Act allows Medicare to negotiate some drug prices, a change that the pharmaceutical industry and Republicans have opposed for decades.
content: As he heads toward a re-election campaign next year, President Biden is betting that his success in pushing for policies intended to lower health care costs for millions of Americans will be rewarded by voters at the ballot box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: U.S. Seeks to Block Recovery of Titanic Artifacts
description: Washington has gone to court to become a party to the salvage case involving the famous liner so it can stop any expedition it deems objectionable.
content: In late 1985, weeks after the shattered remains of the R.M.S. Titanic came to light, officials in Washington began seeking legal authority to regulate access to the famous shipwreck as part of a memorial to the more than 1,500 passengers and crew members who had lost their lives in 1912. Congress called for a global accord, as the wreck lay in international waters. Until then, Congress declared, “no person should physically alter, disturb, or salvage the R.M.S. Titanic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez on How She’s Changed
description: The congresswoman from New York says she’s different from when she first took office. But she’s not ready to call herself an insider.
content: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is used to being a lightning rod. Since her election in 2018, she has been celebrated and vilified by both parties, sometimes simultaneously. Ms. Ocasio-Cortez, though, is no longer the freshman outsider. Now in her third term, with a high-ranking position on a powerful House committee, she has learned to maneuver in Congress, making allies on the left and working with her political adversaries. She says that might make the progressive wing of her party “suspicious,” but she’s comfortable having more influence on the inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Anti-Abortion Activist Who Kept Fetuses Is Convicted in Clinic Blockade
description: Lauren Handy and four others were found guilty of illegally blocking access to a Washington abortion clinic. No charges have been filed in connection with five fetuses that were found in her home last year.
content: Five anti-abortion activists, including one who was found to have kept five fetuses in her home last year, were found guilty of federal civil rights offenses on Tuesday after blocking access to an abortion clinic in Washington, D.C., in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Who Gets the Cloned Dog in the Breakup?
description: A thorny question of custody is complicated by the fact that the reader adopted the original dog, but her ex paid a majority of the $50,000 needed to clone it.
content: My partner and I went through a breakup recently. During our relationship, he developed a close bond with my dog. As the dog grew older, we joked about cloning her to keep her in our lives. If Barbra Streisand could do it, why couldn’t we? Then the joke became a reality: When my dog turned 12, we cloned her. It’s been a joy to see her as a baby! (I rescued her when she was older.) Then came the breakup. I am keeping the older dog, but we can’t agree who should take the younger one. I think of her as part of my dog and want to keep her. He argues this is selfish of me and we should each get a dog in the breakup. (Note: He paid most of the cloning costs, about $50,000, and we share dog care.) Thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: In San Francisco, Hope for ‘Rebirth and Renewal’
description: As he moves to a new role, Thomas Fuller reflects on his time as the bureau chief of a city undergoing a major transformation.
content: Four years ago, when I first met Mark-Steven Holys, a retired sommelier and waiter at high-end restaurants, he was living in a tent by a freeway, not far from the edge of the San Francisco Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Florida Braces for Hurricane Idalia, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.1 Million Homes in Connecticut, Virginia and Idaho
description: A 1790 house in Washington, a three-building compound in Warrenton and a midcentury home in Boise.
content: Since it was built in the late 18th century, this house has been home to the owner of the town’s general store, a clubhouse for Yale athletes and a student dorm for the Frederick Gunn preparatory school. Its proximity to the center of town puts it within walking distance of restaurants and shops. The high-end Mayflower Inn & Spa is less than half a mile away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and John Koblin
title: CNN Is Expected to Pick Mark Thompson as Next Leader
description: Mr. Thompson, who helped revitalize The New York Times, will take over at a pivotal moment for the news network.
content: Mark Thompson, a former chief executive of The New York Times and leader of the BBC, is expected to be named the next top executive of CNN, according to three people with knowledge of the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Ruth Graham
title: Pope Says a Strong U.S. Faction Offers a Backward, Narrow View of the Church
description: In unusually sharp remarks published this week, Pope Francis said some conservative American Catholics wrongly ignore much of the Church’s mission and reject the possibility of change.
content: ROME — Pope Francis has expressed in unusually sharp terms his dismay at “a very strong, organized, reactionary attitude” opposing him within the U.S. Roman Catholic Church, one that fixates on social issues like abortion and sexuality to the exclusion of caring for the poor and the environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Trump Trial Date Is a Big Mistake
description: Why a Super Tuesday court date is bad for both the law and democracy.
content: I intended to write a normal horse-race column this week, about what we can glean from the polling that came out after the first Republican debate. The emphasis was going to be on the resilience of Ron DeSantis, the success of Nikki Haley, the modest perils for Donald Trump in not showing up for these affairs — and then the larger problem of how DeSantis or Haley or anyone else might unite the anti-Trump vote instead of just repeating the fragmentation of 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Jean
title: Water Is Essential to Life. How Could It Ever Go Out of Style?
description: The fashion world has long been fascinated with the natural world, but the love affair poses one major challenge: how to create the (convincing) illusion of wetness.
content: In preparation for her head-turning appearance at the 2019 Met Gala, Kim Kardashian met with the fashion designer Thierry Mugler to conceptualize her look. “Who are you, actually?” the designer asked her, according to Mr. Mugler’s manager at the time. “How would you define yourself?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: The Faustian Bargain of Reducing Air Pollution
description: Some aerial contaminants, like sulfur, cool the climate.
content: This summer of extremes has been a summer of mystery, debate and even some confusion for climate scientists, who’ve been watching the news with the rest of us and asking, What, exactly, is going on?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Do Cocktail Glasses Have a Gender? For Some Men, the Answer Is Clear.
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 30, 2023.
content: “As a society, we’re working toward dismantling gender roles and gender dynamics. Why is this the one little thing that we’re still holding on to?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: A Meal in France Showed Me the Brilliance of Simplicity
description: An ordinary, unfussy meal can still contain wonders.
content: It was late June, and the sun would not set. The hotel room had two beds side by side, “each just slightly wider than the human body,” I wrote in the diary that I kept for that week and that week only, then buried in a box for many years. The bathroom was hot and airless; the towels were thin. The one window looked out on a roof heaped with rusted scraps. And so I found myself on the Côte d’Azur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Chevlen and Magdalena Wosinska
title: Ballet Is a Great Workout for an Aging Body
description: Classes for ‘silver swans’ can help you improve balance and find joy.
content: At Studio A in Los Angeles, Diane Kravif, 75, stands at the barre with pin-straight posture. Pink slippers cover her feet, and her silver bob is pushed back with a headband. Watching her tendu and plié, you might assume she has danced forever. But it has been only four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanine Barone
title: In the Faroe Islands, Art, Food and Fashion Take a Cue From Nature
description: Tórshavn, the cosmopolitan capital of this North Atlantic archipelago, is surrounded by otherworldly scenery that fuels the creative spirit.
content: Huddled in the North Atlantic between Iceland, Scotland and Norway, the Faroes — an 18-island archipelago and self-governing nation within the Kingdom of Denmark — captivates visitors the instant they land at the airport on the island of Vágar. Silence saturates the emerald green slopes and basalt cliffs. Sheep roam the grassy expanses that are sliced vertically by dark rocky threads caused by the erosion of streams. It’s hard to keep your eyes focused on the road as you behold a gauzy mist swirling around the mountains, veiling deep gorges, wide fjords, occasional turf-roofed dwellings and waterfalls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maya King
title: After Jacksonville, Tensions Flare Between DeSantis and Black Floridians
description: At a vigil for the shooting victims, Mr. DeSantis had to speak over loud boos from a largely Black crowd. His agenda in Florida has earned him few Black allies.
content: Days after being sworn in as Florida’s governor in 2019, Ron DeSantis pardoned the Groveland Four, a group of Black men who had been wrongfully accused of sexually assaulting a white woman decades earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Mounting Losses Shake China’s Biggest Homebuilder
description: Country Garden, already on the brink of default with nearly $190 billion in debt, reported billions in losses for the first half of the year.
content: The embattled Chinese homebuilder Country Garden said on Wednesday that it lost $7.1 billion in the first six months of the year, intensifying the pressure on China’s biggest property developer as it teeters on the verge of financial collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Last Defendant in Trump Election Interference Case in Georgia Is Granted Bond
description: Harrison William Prescott Floyd, who once led a group called Black Voices for Trump, was held longer at an Atlanta jail after turning himself in, apparently because he showed up to his booking without a lawyer.
content: Harrison William Prescott Floyd, a supporter of Donald J. Trump’s who was indicted along with the former president in the Georgia election interference case, was granted a $100,000 bond on Tuesday, the last of the 19 defendants in the case to reach a bond agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Richard Ekstract, Magazine Publisher With Link to Warhol, Dies at 92
description: He was promoting a new trade journal, Tape Recording, when he lent a video recorder to Andy Warhol, who used it to make a classic work with Edie Sedgwick.
content: Richard Ekstract, a magazine publisher who found success with niche audiences — from trade journals like Tape Recording and Audio Times to a regional shelter franchise that started with Hamptons Cottages and Gardens — and played a curious role in Andy Warhol’s career, died on Aug. 7 in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhoda Feng
title: Review: In ‘Pay the Writer,’ a Portrait of the Artist Young and Old
description: Despite its thunderbolt of a title, the focus of this memory play is on the relationship between a self-involved author and his long-suffering agent.
content: Amid an ongoing strike by Hollywood screenwriters and actors, a play with the nifty title “Pay the Writer” courts applause before anyone has uttered a word. Never mind that its turf is mainly the literary world, not the cinematic one; the author at the center of Tawni O’Dell’s play, Cyrus Holt (Ron Canada), seems to speak for all underpaid writers when he inscribes that feisty injunction in a copy of his book that is being adapted as a movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Sadie Dupuis Confronts Her Darkest Memories on Speedy Ortiz’s New LP
description: The indie rocker found herself writing about what she had long suppressed on “Rabbit Rabbit,” due Friday.
content: “Ask me anything, even if it’s painful,” Sadie Dupuis sings on “Rabbit Rabbit,” the fifth album by her band Speedy Ortiz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Labor Dept. Proposes Vast Expansion of Overtime Eligibility
description: The Biden administration seeks a threshold of about $55,000 in annual pay under which salaried workers must receive overtime, up from $35,500.
content: In a move that could affect millions of workers, the Biden administration announced Wednesday that it was proposing to substantially increase the cutoff below which most salaried workers automatically receive time-and-a-half overtime pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Taco Soup Is Summer and Fall in One Spicy, Satisfying Bowl
description: Also bright and comforting: spiced eggplant with tomatoes and runny eggs, Melissa Clark’s genius twist on shakshuka.
content: Hi there! We’re so close to the holiday weekend, let’s ignore some emails and think about food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Nelson
title: H.B.O. Is Tackling Religion in the Most Remarkable Ways
description: “The Righteous Gemstones” remains a surprisingly complex (and hilarious) take on American faith.
content: It’s hard to find a doctrine that better explains this country’s political and cultural trajectory over the past 50 years than the so-called prosperity gospel, which reversed the old dogma in one key, seductive way: It came to interpret the attainment of worldly wealth and privilege as proof of spiritual exceptionalism, the rewards of a life lived righteously. Jesus says in Matthew 19:24: “And I say again unto you — it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.” But across the end of the 20th century, any number of figures built immense and lucrative flocks by coming at that problem from a very different direction: a promise, perhaps, that you might look great crossing into heaven in a camel-hair suit. That this sentiment aligned so well with politically ascendant strains of conservatism may or may not be coincidence, but the net effect was the same. There is the elevation of wealth as a sign of virtue. There is the sense that if only those in need had been more righteous, they, too, might have been blessed. There is, in short, the long, strange trajectory of American temperament that has, on some level, brought us to HBO’s “The Righteous Gemstones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Wind Energy Giant Orsted Says Delays in U.S. May Cost $2 Billion
description: Supply chain problems and high interest rates are hurting U.S. projects, the Danish company said.
content: Orsted, the Danish renewable energy giant, has warned that it may write off as much as $2.12 billion because of supply chain problems and other issues at three giant offshore wind installations off the United States’ East Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Bird Flu Raced Through South America. Antarctica Could Be Next.
description: More than 100 million birds breed in the region, and many are likely to be vulnerable to the virus, scientists warned.
content: Over the last three years, a highly lethal form of avian influenza has whipped around the world, felling birds in Europe, Africa and Asia before jumping across the ocean and setting off the worst bird flu outbreak in United States history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Typhoon Saola, Nearing Category 5 Strength, Threatens China
description: The tropical cyclone was passing near Taiwan on Wednesday and edging closer to Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland.
content: Typhoon Saola, a powerful tropical cyclone with wind speeds approaching those of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes, was passing close to Taiwan on Wednesday. It was also edging northward toward Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and Robin Pogrebin
title: Henry Timms Wants to Tear Down Walls at Lincoln Center
description: With David Geffen Hall open, Lincoln Center’s leader is working to diversify programming, staff and audiences and engage the city. But some worry about what’s being lost.
content: For evidence that all is not business as usual at Lincoln Center these days, look no further than its stately travertine campus, which, for much of the summer, was dominated by a giant glittering disco ball, pink and purple flowers painted on the sidewalk and a flock of 200 flamingo lawn ornaments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Once in a (Super) Blue Moon
description: The second full moon in August is tonight. And it’s a big one.
content: Good morning. Today we’ll look at what makes tonight’s full moon especially special.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: putative
description: This word has appeared in 49 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word putative has appeared in 49 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 8 in “The End of the Magic World’s 50-Year Grudge” by David Segal:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: McConnell Freezes Up a Second Time While Addressing Reporters
description: The episode, which took place in the Republican leader’s home state of Kentucky, intensified questions about his future in the Senate.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the longtime Republican leader who has appeared increasingly diminished and frail after a series of falls and a serious head injury this year, froze up suddenly during a news conference on Wednesday in Covington, Ky., the second such episode he has experienced on camera in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: When 19 Makes You the Veteran Player at the U.S. Open
description: Coco Gauff, at 19, was three years older than her latest opponent in the tournament, Mirra Andreeva, who turned professional last year.
content: As Coco Gauff and Mirra Andreeva faced off at the U.S. Open on Wednesday, fans in the stands remarked about how old — really how young — they were while competing at the top of their sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pascale Bonnefoy
title: Decades After Dictatorship, Chile Mounts Search for Hundreds Who Vanished
description: President Gabriel Boric authorized a new national search plan ahead of the 50th anniversary of the coup that toppled the government and led to the disappearance and killing of thousands.
content: Thirty-six years after Fernando Ortíz’s abduction and disappearance, his family finally received his remains: five bone fragments in a box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mary Wilson, Diana Nguyen, Summer Thomad, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: A Breakout Moment for Vivek Ramaswamy
description: The message and strategy of the republican newcomer.
content: In the Republican presidential race, the battle for second place has been jolted by the sudden rise of a political newcomer whose popularity has already eclipsed that of far more seasoned candidates — Vivek Ramaswamy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: The Fight to Control Big Gay Ice Cream, Which Made the Rainbow Its Brand
description: A company that rode to success with an inclusive message has shrunk to a single store, as a founder sues a partner he accuses of mismanagement and fraud.
content: It was all rainbows and unicorns for a while. But like many fun ideas, Big Gay Ice Cream has wound up in debt and in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Venice Film Festival: No Zendaya as the Strikes Change the Picture
description: Day 1 brought challenges but not “Challengers,” the film that had been scheduled to open this usually starry event until it was delayed by the strikes.
content: The sky in Venice wept on Wednesday, for there were no pictures to be taken of Zendaya in couture clambering from a speedboat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: On the Coney Island Boardwalk, It’s the Summer of Snakes (and a Wallaby)
description: The authorities recently confiscated an unusual pet that a man brought to the beach, highlighting what has become an impromptu petting zoo.
content: When a 13-year-old girl drapes a huge snake over your shoulders in front of hundreds of people on the Coney Island boardwalk, the obvious questions — What is her deal? Why am I doing this? — fall away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harron Walker
title: The Bar That Will Do Anything to Make You Feel ‘Insane and Alive’
description: Singers has played host to sauna raves, pop-up petting zoos and the most perfectly deranged Olympic Games imaginable: cigarette races.
content: Maybe you’ve seen it on social media? That delightfully absurd scene: a dozen or so people, tightly packed and shrouded in a smoky haze, racing to finish their cigarettes. The competitors would go on to wrestle in a kiddie pool filled with lube and compete in other events by day’s end, all in pursuit of the grand prize: a voucher for fillers and Botox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Idalia Could Become Another Multibillion-Dollar Superstorm
description: The Category 3 hurricane could expose insurers and their customers to huge losses across a wide stretch of Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas.
content: Hurricane Idalia strengthened to a Category 3 storm on Wednesday morning, packing soaking rains and destructive winds of up to 125 miles per hour, as it lumbers toward the Florida coastline. Officials along Florida’s Gulf Coast and in Georgia and the Carolinas have issued emergency warnings, as the region braces for yet another “multibillion-dollar insurance industry event.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: On Their High Horse, Too Many Liberals Disdain Oliver Anthony
description: Democrats wag their fingers at a blue-collar singer when they should be applauding his core message about left-behind Americans.
content: What’s wrong here?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: ‘The Right Thing to Do’: Starter Throws 131 Pitches in One-Hitter
description: Alex Cobb of the San Francisco Giants gave up a hit with two outs in the ninth but finished what he started. It was the most pitches in a game since 2019.
content: Clinging to a no-hitter with two outs in the ninth inning on Tuesday, Alex Cobb of the San Francisco Giants fired his 125th pitch of the night — an 89-mile-an-hour splitter — and Cincinnati’s Spencer Steer lined it to center field to double in a run.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 30, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 30, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about new nations invited to join the BRICS club misstated the status of Argentina, Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. They have been invited to join the BRICS group of nations; they have not already joined. Because of an editing error, a picture caption also referred imprecisely to President Ebrahim Raisi. He was pictured on a screen addressing the BRICS summit, but he was not attending the event remotely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Use Your Phone as a Pocket Tutor for Study on the Go
description: Apps that offer short lessons in various subjects can help get the most out of your time whether you’re waiting for a train or a meeting.
content: Autumn is edging closer, and the return to a more regular office schedule looms for many people — and with it, the waiting time for transportation, meetings and appointments. Games, reading, social-media scrolls or just zoning out are common ways to spend these spells, but if you want more mental stimulation, why not boost your brain with brief lessons in subjects that interest you? Here’s a guide to finding Android and iOS apps that turn your smartphone into a traveling pocket tutor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Military Officers Seize Power in Gabon, Threatening an African Dynasty
description: The coup was announced hours after President Ali Bongo Ondimba, whose family has controlled the country for a half-century, was declared to have been re-elected for a third term in a disputed election.
content: Military officers said they had seized power in the oil-rich Central African nation of Gabon early on Wednesday, overturning the results of a disputed election that returned the incumbent, President Ali Bongo Ondimba, to a third term in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Lynn
title: Astoria, Queens: ‘A Mix of Traditional and Trendy’
description: With relatively affordable prices and an easy commute to Manhattan, the area is attracting new residents, but it still has a strong sense of community.
content: Catherine Seaman and Tom Metzger were living in a small, sixth-floor walk-up in the Hell’s Kitchen neighborhood of Manhattan in 2022 when they decided that Mr. Metzger, 33, a construction consultant, would need more space if he were going to work comfortably from home. And if they were going to move, Dr. Seaman, 31, a gynecologist, needed an easy commute to Mount Sinai Hospital on the Upper East Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Trader Joe’s Recalls Tamales, the Company’s Sixth Since July
description: The company cited potential milk contamination of the tamales. Other products had potentially been contaminated with rocks, insects and metal.
content: Trader Joe’s has issued a recall of a brand of black bean tamales, the sixth item that the popular grocery chain has recalled since July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Outbreak of Legionnaires’ Disease in Poland Kills 16
description: Infections have surged in Rzeszow, whose strategic location near the Ukrainian border has transformed it into a hub for the Western response to Russia’s invasion.
content: Sixteen people have died and over 150 have been hospitalized in southeastern Poland in an outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease, a severe strain of bacterial pneumonia, local health authorities said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paulette Perhach
title: For Women With Money Issues, an A.D.H.D. Diagnosis Can Be Revelatory
description: A diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in adulthood has solved a mystery for some women, helping them get control over their finances.
content: Seven years ago, I wrote an essay about what life would feel like if I didn’t struggle with saving money. In it, I envisioned the power of having enough in emergency funds to tide me over in case I needed to leave an abusive job or relationship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman and Noah Weiland
title: Narcan Is Headed to Stores: What You Need to Know
description: The overdose-reversal drug should be more widely available, health experts have said. It arrives in many stores next week, no prescription necessary.
content: Narcan, the first opioid overdose reversal medication approved for over-the-counter purchase, is being shipped to drugstore and grocery chains nationwide, its manufacturer said Wednesday. Big-box outlets like Walgreens, CVS, Walmart and Rite Aid said they expected Narcan to be available online and on many store shelves early next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: How Three Visionaries Expanded Our Understanding of Reality
description: “The Rigor of Angels,” by William Egginton, considers how three very different men — Jorge Luis Borges, Immanuel Kant and Werner Heisenberg — rejected conventional assumptions about reality and embraced paradoxical truths instead.
content: Chances are, if you have ever heard the story of Solomon Shereshevsky, you haven’t forgotten it. Shereshevsky’s powers of memory were so remarkable that in 1929 he gave up his job as a journalist in Moscow and joined the circus. He could recite lists of numbers, poems in foreign languages, even strings of random syllables that were called out to him from the audience. His world was abundant in particulars, brimming with imagery and sensations. When asked to share his understanding of the number 87, he said he envisioned it as “a fat woman and a man twirling his mustache.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: ‘We Should Have Gotten Off the Island’: Cedar Key Residents Survived Idalia’s Wrath
description: Much of Cedar Key, a series of tiny islands that jut into the Gulf, was covered by storm surge overnight as the hurricane came ashore.
content: Hours after the waters of the Gulf of Mexico swept through her house, Donna Knight emerged in a windbreaker and boots to try to get her Chevy SUV to higher ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones and Sara Novak
title: Idalia and a ‘Supermoon’ Could Swamp Charleston and Savannah
description: A full moon is passing close to earth, exerting a greater gravitational pull and creating higher tides than usual, just as the storm is forecast to push more water ashore.
content: Hurricane Idalia will amplify what were already expected to be higher-than-usual high tides in Savannah, Ga., and Charleston, S.C., because the full moon is making its closest orbital pass to Earth, a rare phenomenon sometimes known as a ‘supermoon.’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Finnegan
title: Trump Joins George Washington, John Quincy Adams and Barack Obama
description: Whether their portraits were in oil paint or digital photography, presidents have always sought the same thing: control.
content: Eagerly anticipated and immediately meme-ified, the mug shot of Donald Trump that the Fulton County Sheriff’s Office circulated last week was in some ways utterly conventional: a head-and-shoulders view with unflattering lighting and a law enforcement logo in the corner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Ben Protess
title: Giuliani Is Liable for Defaming Georgia Election Workers, Judge Says
description: The ruling means that a defamation case against Rudolph W. Giuliani, stemming from his role in seeking to overturn the 2020 election, can proceed to a trial where damages will be considered.
content: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that Rudolph W. Giuliani was liable for defaming two Georgia election workers by repeatedly declaring that they had mishandled ballots while counting votes in Atlanta during the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Women May Face Higher Risk of Stroke Following Infertility Treatment
description: In the largest study of its kind, scientists found higher odds of stroke after childbirth among women who had received the treatments. Still, the number of strokes remained very low overall.
content: Women who became pregnant after infertility treatment were more likely to have a stroke in the year following the birth when compared with women who conceived naturally, scientists reported on Wednesday in the largest study of its kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: Trump Asks to Dismiss Suit as A.G. Says He Inflated Worth by $2.2 Billion
description: Letitia James, the attorney general, asked a judge to find, without a trial, that the former president had fraudulently overvalued his assets.
content: Before Donald J. Trump was indicted four times over, he was sued by New York’s attorney general, who said that for years the former president, his business and members of his family had fraudulently overvalued their assets by billions of dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: A Grand Slam Rite of Passage: Be Young, Burn Bright, but Not for Long
description: At the U.S. Open, Arthur Fils, a 19-year-old Frenchman, is surpassing expectations. Britain’s Jack Draper, 21, has been there. It’s all good.
content: It happens every year in tennis. Actually, four times a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! I Fell in Sicily and my Travel Insurance Ditched Me
description: Badly hurt, a 68-year-old solo traveler expected her insurer to coordinate her care, provide much-needed translation services and then return her home to Florida. Was she expecting too much?
content: I’m a 68-year-old solo traveler who was on a tour of Sicily in June 2022, when I fell getting off a bus, breaking multiple ribs, vertebrae and a pelvic bone. I had purchased the RoundTrip Choice plan from Seven Corners Travel Insurance, so I called, expecting they would help coordinate my medical care with Italian-speaking doctors. But they told me to seek help on my own, save the receipts and file a claim when I got home. Our tour guide was an angel, arranging drivers to take me back and forth to the hospital and even interpreting by speakerphone with doctors. Days later I got a doctor to fill out a form (which I had to Google Translate for him) saying I could travel home, as long as I was in a reclining position. My family chipped in to buy a business-class seat for the return flight, a day-and-night trip from Palermo to Munich to New York to Jacksonville. Seven Corners finally paid $5,772 for my bills and missed trip, but refused to reimburse me for most of my business-class fare. Far worse, I believe they failed to provide me the assistance they promised, essentially leaving me to fend for myself and leaving me unable to communicate with hospital staff. I have registered complaints with the Better Business Bureau and the state insurance agencies of Florida and Indiana (where Seven Corners is based), but I’ve gotten nowhere. Can you help? Helaine, St. Augustine, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: What’s Stopping Ukraine From Flying F-16s
description: Ukraine’s sense of urgency in obtaining the fighter jet reflects concerns about the war against Russia, but also the political calendar in the West. But training pilots and support crew is a lengthy process.
content: The F-16 fighter jets would not be delivered to Ukraine until next year, but that did not dissuade President Volodymyr Zelensky from hopping into one last week in the Netherlands — one stop on a European tour to collect commitments to donate the warplane as quickly as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Philadelphia Asks if Race of Tubman Sculptor Matters
description: A white artist was invited to design a statue of Harriet Tubman. After complaints, the city held an open call for submissions.
content: A year ago, the city of Philadelphia invited an artist to design a statue of Harriet Tubman that would stand in front of City Hall to honor the abolitionist’s legacy and celebrate her connection to the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Tested in Greece’s Fires: An Emergency Force for 27 Countries
description: The European Union deployed firefighters and equipment in what could be a preview of how it handles disasters linked to climate change.
content: At dusk last week in the picturesque northern Greek village of Dadia, home to a few hundred people and next to a lush national park full of rare vultures, dozens of firefighters from around Europe gathered to assess the day’s work and load up on water and fuel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Stulberg
title: Stop Resisting Change
description: With the right mind-set, adapting to change can be a force for growth.
content: The Greek philosopher Heraclitus taught that you can’t step into the same river twice, for you aren’t the same person at each visit, and the water is ever flowing. It is a powerful way to represent the reality of impermanence: Everything is always changing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: The Art of Being a Morning Person (Even if You’re Actually Not One)
description: Night owls may never truly love the early hours. But there are simple ways to make them feel a little less painful.
content: My older child has always been an early riser. He rarely snoozes past 6 a.m.; 6:30 is a miracle. He bounces out of bed as my husband and I clench our coffees, greeting his enthusiasm for the day with a lot of halfhearted grunting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Standout Korean Spots for Standbys, Knife-Cut Noodles and More
description: New York’s high-end Korean restaurants are impressive. They’re also expensive. Here are seven options where you won’t go broke.
content: I wrote this week about the rapid rise in Manhattan of Korean restaurants that qualify as fine dining, including Jungsik, Atomix, Cote and Oiji Mi. The term fine dining implies a certain attentiveness in service and, on the plate, an attention to detail that can become quite elaborate. The most useful way to define it, though, is as a price bracket. With some exceptions, fine dining is more expensive than other styles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Laszlo Birinyi, Leading Stock Picker and Market Forecaster, Dies at 79
description: His investment strategy, which tracked the flow of money, won him a reputation for prescience in the 1990s.
content: Laszlo Birinyi, an investor who declared that he took little interest in corporate news, financial algorithms and even the economy itself, and who instead “listened” to the market, as he put it, developing a theory about the flow of money that made him one of the nation’s foremost stock pickers in the 1990s, died on Aug. 21 at his home in Southport, Conn. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe) Mailbag: Selena Gomez, BTS and Doja Cat!
description: Listener and viewer questions on some recent releases, also including Renee Rapp, Earl Sweatshirt and Zach Bryan.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, is comprised completely of viewer and listener questions, and includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: A Shocking Soccer Kiss Demonstrates the Power of Scandal
description: By generating public outrage, scandals make inaction costly: suddenly, doing nothing carries greater risks.
content: After Luis Rubiales, the president of Spain’s soccer federation, forcibly kissed Jennifer Hermoso, a player on the national women’s team, in the wake of their World Cup win, many wondered whether it would be a #MeToo moment for Spain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Two Years After Afghanistan Exit, Biden Resists Calls for More Taliban Contact
description: Some U.S. officials had clung to the hope that the Taliban had moderated since they last controlled the country in the 1990s.
content: When the last American soldier flew out of Afghanistan on Aug. 30, 2021, leaving the country to Taliban rule, the world braced for a human rights nightmare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Esserman and Scott Eggener
title: Not Everything We Call Cancer Should Be Called Cancer
description: Calling something cancer can lead to aggressive treatment even if the cancer in question is unlikely to cause problems.
content: “You have cancer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: ‘This Is a Test’: Nationwide Alert Will Reach Cellphones, TVs and Radios
description: Federal agencies will send the alerts on Oct. 4 to ensure that the country is prepared to inform the public in the event of a large-scale emergency.
content: Testing. One. Two. Three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Thomas Fuller
title: Idalia Brings Surge of Seawater, but Less Damage Than Feared
description: The storm, which made landfall in a sparsely populated area, wrecked homes and businesses but was not as fierce as Hurricane Ian last year, which was responsible for 150 deaths.
content: Hurricane Idalia, the first major storm to pummel Florida this season, brought a surge of seawater on Wednesday that flooded neighborhoods along much of the state’s western coast and lacerating winds that cut power and leveled trees. Two people died in traffic accidents that the police linked to the harsh conditions. Rescuers pulled scores of people from homes that were taking on water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter and Stacy Cowley
title: Voice Deepfakes Are Coming for Your Bank Balance
description: Artificial intelligence tools have given scammers a potent weapon for trying to trick people into sending them money.
content: This spring, Clive Kabatznik, an investor in Florida, called his local Bank of America representative to discuss a big money transfer he was planning to make. Then he called again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Yeung
title: Parisians Are Pledging Allegiance to the ‘Republic of Super Neighbors.’ They Must Bring Cheese.
description: A grass-roots movement aims to recast urban living in Paris and other cities around the world through a hyperlocal prism of neighborliness.
content: A series about how cities transform, and the effect of that on everyday life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Natasha Frost
title: Will a Bitterly Divided Australia Elevate the Voice of Aboriginal People?
description: A referendum to set up an Indigenous advisory body in Parliament was envisioned as uniting the country. The opposite has happened.
content: It was billed as a modest proposal that would help heal the traumas of history and unite the country. Australia would change its Constitution to recognize the original inhabitants of the land and enshrine an advisory body in Parliament for Aboriginal people, giving them a greater say on issues that affect their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yasmina Price
title: Ja’Tovia Gary Sets Her Sights on Love
description: The experimental artist discusses Black Southern storytelling, the blues and the guilt-free pleasures of a romance novel.
content: “I’m really excited to return to the garden and see what it brings,” says the conceptual artist Ja’Tovia Gary, 39. The garden in question is “The Giverny Suite” (2019), her densely layered three-channel video installation that will be on view at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, as a new addition to its collection, starting Sept. 1. In one of the suite’s segments, Gary visits Claude Monet’s garden at Giverny, in the Normandy region of France, staging herself as an errant presence within its manufactured perfection; as she roams the grounds, she suddenly disappears amid precisely arranged trees, and abruptly starts screaming by the water lily pond, inserting glitches into the image. Elsewhere in the suite, Gary treats a street corner in Harlem like its own discrete ecosystem, paying close attention to how Black women inhabit the space. “The Giverny Suite,” much like her practice in general, traverses geographies and histories while employing an array of experimental techniques. Yet the installation also coheres around a singular vision — one of autonomy and safety for Black women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor, Jonathan Weisman and Maggie Haberman
title: Emulating Trump, Ramaswamy Shows a Penchant for Dispensing With the Facts
description: In clashes with the news media and his rivals, the Republican upstart has retreated from past comments and lied about on-the-record statements.
content: In his breakout performance in the Republican primary race, Vivek Ramaswamy has harnessed his populist bravado while frequently and unapologetically contorting the truth for political gain, much in the same way that former President Donald J. Trump has mastered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Most Famous Woman in Men’s Tennis
description: The fashion influencer Morgan Riddle has become a niche celebrity at professional tennis matches, where she cheers for her boyfriend, the American player Taylor Fritz, as some fans cheer for her.
content: Morgan Riddle was being watched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Daring Deed
description: We’ve caught wind of something going on in this crossword by Alex Eaton-Salners.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Jonathan Weisman
title: Is Trump Disqualified? Republicans Prepare to Fight Long-Shot Legal Theory.
description: In New Hampshire, Republicans are feuding over whether the 14th Amendment bars Donald J. Trump from running for president. Other states are watching closely.
content: New Hampshire’s first-in-the-nation primary is quickly becoming the leading edge for an unproven legal theory that Donald J. Trump is disqualified from appearing on the ballot under the 14th Amendment of the U.S. Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Many Children May Have Lost Medicaid Coverage Because of State Errors
description: Federal officials warned state agencies to review their systems for establishing eligibility, as they pare back Medicaid rolls. Children in particular may have been affected.
content: Federal officials have discovered major errors in the systems and procedures that some states have been using to verify eligibility for Medicaid, possibly leading to a substantial number of children losing health coverage despite still being eligible for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
title: Trump, Under Oath, Says He Averted ‘Nuclear Holocaust’
description: During a deposition in his civil case, the former president offered a series of defenses, digressions and meandering explanations of his political and professional dealings.
content: Under oath and under fire, Donald J. Trump sat for a seven-hour interview with the New York attorney general’s office in April, part of the civil fraud case against him and his company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Victoria Kim
title: Dueling Aerial Assaults Hit Ukraine and Russia
description: Four military cargo planes at a Russia airfield were damaged, and the Kyiv region was hit with one of the most significant missile and drone barrages in months.
content: A wave of exploding drones was launched in six regions of Russia overnight Wednesday, Russian officials said, damaging four military cargo planes at an airfield 30 miles from the border with Estonia, a NATO member, in an apparent sign that Ukraine was increasingly capable of striking back deep inside Moscow’s territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lyna Bentahar
title: Thursday Briefing: Drone Attacks Reach Deep Into Russia
description: Also, a referendum divides Australia.
content: Exploding drones attacked six regions of Russia yesterday morning, suggesting that, after months of enduring missile and drone strikes with little recourse, Ukraine is increasingly able to hit back deep inside Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Maggie Haberman, Charlie Savage and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Could Clinch the Nomination Before the G.O.P. Knows if He’s a Felon
description: The federal election interference case — one of four — is set to start just before Super Tuesday and a cascade of consequential primaries.
content: By the time Donald J. Trump is sitting at his federal trial on charges of criminally conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, he may have already secured enough delegates to effectively clinch the Republican Party’s 2024 presidential nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron Tries Outreach to Head Off Further Protests
description: After a tumultuous year, the French president is meeting with his opponents in hopes of building bridges. But few seem interested in working with him.
content: For over six years, President Emmanuel Macron has struggled to convince the French that he is a man of dialogue. He went on a countrywide listening tour to calm the storms of the Yellow Vest uprising, convened a citizen convention on climate policy, and created a council of politicians and members of civil society to discuss France’s most pressing issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: A Quest Inspired By the Pandemic Seed Shortage and a ‘Primal Fear’
description: When one gardener realized there was no seed available to order, she panicked and then began asking questions. Her new book offers some answers.
content: When the pandemic lockdowns began, Jennifer Jewell, a garden writer and podcaster, was traveling on an East Coast speaking tour. She and her partner, John Whittlesey, planned to be away from their Butte County, Calif., home for weeks, so they had skipped their usual spring vegetable-garden preparations, including ordering seeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Levitt, Yuliya Parshina-Kottas, Simon Romero and Tim Wallace
title: ‘War Against the Children’
description: New research reveals the vast scope of the Native American boarding school system, which for more than a century removed Native children from their homes and families in an effort to assimilate them. Students at the schools gave up their names, their labor and sometimes their lives.
content: New research reveals the vast scope of the Native American boarding school system, which for more than a century removed Native children from their homes and families in an effort to assimilate them. Students at the schools gave up their names, their labor and sometimes their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Take Somebody’s Help and Get Out’: Hurricane Idalia Floods Florida Town
description: A father and daughter rescue team warned residents of Crystal River, Fla., to evacuate as floodwaters started to rise after Hurricane Idalia made landfall.
